head.title: Can Blacks Afford Not to Vote?

hedline.hl1: Can Blacks Afford Not to Vote?

abstract.p: David Gutmann letter on black anti-Semitism revealed in reaction to vice presidential nomination of Sen Joseph Lieberman; warns that references to 'wealthy Jews' have noxious meanings (S)

block.p: David A. Bositis (Op-Ed, Aug. 17) makes light of black anti-Semitic attitudes that have been revealed by Anti-Defamation League studies and by the Democratic Party's nomination of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman to be vice president.

Mr. Bositis says that the many black references to Jewish wealth do not betoken any special hostility to Jews, as poor blacks often refer to ''all white people'' in the same terms. But there is a special burden of noxious meanings that are almost always carried by the terms ''wealth'' and ''wealthy'' when applied to Jews. The ''wealthy Jew'' is by implication a usurer, a Fagin, a Shylock: he has not acquired wealth by honest toil but by oppressing, corrupting and robbing others.

Mr. Bositis says that the many black references to Jewish wealth do not betoken any special hostility to Jews, as poor blacks often refer to ''all white people'' in the same terms. But there is a special burden of noxious meanings that are almost always carried by the terms ''wealth'' and ''wealthy'' when applied to Jews. The ''wealthy Jew'' is by implication a usurer, a Fagin, a Shylock: he has not acquired wealth by honest toil but by oppressing, corrupting and robbing others.
Such epithets are too often, across history and cultures, the preludes to anti-Semitic pogroms and murder.
